page.title: 15FLOWERS IN LITTONDALE
page.content: The most widespread wayside flower in summer is sweet cicely, replaced later by meadowsweet and meadow cranesbill. As well as the more common flowers, ox-eye daisy, scabious, valerian, Jacobs ladder and harebell are found on uncut verges. Primrose and cowslip still occur but are decreasing. Giant bell-flower, the rare Saracen's woundwort and lilies of the valley are found. Kingcups, mimulus, wood aven and brooklime are found by streams, bird's-eye primrose, butterwort and mountain pansy on fellsides along with thyme, milkwort, tormentil and rockrose. Betony grows on damp pastures. In the grikes on the limestone pavements wood anemone, wood-sorrel, hart's-tongue fern and herb robert survive as relics of ancient woodland as well as on the valley bottom.
